Definition / general

* Rare oral manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, particularly ulcerative colitis, characterized by diffuse, vegetative lesions of the oral mucosa ([J Am Acad Dermatol 1989;21:381](2666469), [J Cutan Med Surg 2003;7:250](12574902), [Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))

Essential features

* It is estimated that 73% of cases of pyostomatitis vegetans are associated with gastrointestinal diseases, notably inflammatory bowel disease ([J Am Acad Dermatol 1989;21:381](2666469))
  + 70% of patients with pyostomatitis vegetans have underlying ulcerative colitis, while Crohn's disease is only seen in 11% of cases ([J Cutan Med Surg 2003;7:250](12574902))* 90% of patients with pyostomatitis vegetans exhibit peripheral eosinophilia (absolute eosinophil count > 450 - 500 cells/μL in the peripheral blood) ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389), [Prim Care 2016;43:607](27866580), [Ann Gastroenterol 2013;26:187](24714872))* Pyostomatitis vegetans affects the attached and nonattached oral mucosa but usually spares the tongue and the floor of the mouth
      + Lesions consist of multiple, vegetating yellow pustules that merge and rupture, forming mucosal folds and fissures with a snail track appearance ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))* Histopathologically, pyostomatitis vegetans has pronounced intraepithelial edema and spongiosis that resembles acantholysis; this spongiosis is due to both intraepithelial abscesses with eosinophils and the presence of a mixed subepithelial inflammatory infiltrate ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))

Terminology

* In 1889, French dermatologist François Henri Hallopeau described a new form of chronic pustular dermatitis, which he coined pyodermatite végétante (pyoderma vegetans in English) ([Arch Derm Syphilol 1949;60:750](15390449))
  + In Greek, pyoderma translates to pus in skin and vegetans describes the heaped up, vegetative morphology of lesions* In 1949, oral medicine pioneer Francis P. McCarthy was the first to describe the oral manifestations of this entity in 3 patients and proposed the term pyostomatitis vegetans (in Greek, pyostomatitis means inflammation of the mouth with pus) ([Arch Derm Syphilol 1949;60:750](15390449))
    + That same year, Brunsting and Underwood reported 5 cases of pyoderma vegetans associated with ulcerative colitis and found that managing the colitis led to improvement of the skin condition ([Arch Derm Syphilol 1949;60:161](18133445))* In 1963, Philip McCarthy and Shklar identified an association between pyostomatitis vegetans and ulcerative colitis in 6 patients ([Arch Dermatol 1963;88:913](14071470))* In 1981, Cataldo, Covino and Tesone were the first to report pyostomatitis vegetans in association with Crohn's disease ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1983;55:363](6574415))* Pyodermatitis and pyostomatitis vegetans are part of the same disease process; as such, some authors choose to hyphenate the 2 conditions (i.e., pyodermatitis-pyostomatitis vegetans) ([Acta Derm Venereol 2001;81:134](11501652))

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [L08.81](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/L00-L99/L00-L08/L08-/L08.81) - pyoderma vegetans* ICD-11: [EL3Y](https://icd.who.int/browse/2025-01/mms/en#141396655%2Fother) - other specified cutaneous markers of internal disorders

Epidemiology

* ~73% of cases of pyostomatitis vegetans are associated with gastrointestinal pathoses, particularly inflammatory bowel disease ([J Am Acad Dermatol 1989;21:381](2666469))
  + Ulcerative colitis is strongly associated with pyostomatitis vegetans, affecting 70% of patients, while Crohn's disease is identified in only 11% of cases ([J Cutan Med Surg 2003;7:250](12574902))* Pyostomatitis vegetans is most frequently seen in young and middle aged adults with a strong male predilection (M:F = 3:1) ([Clin Exp Dermatol 2004;29:1](14723710))

Sites

* Inflammatory bowel disease often precedes the development of cutaneous and oral lesions by months or even years ([Ophthalmology 2005;112:1809](16095701))
  + In the oral cavity, the facial and buccal gingiva, hard and soft palatal mucosa, labial and buccal mucosa and vestibular and tonsillar regions are most often affected, while the floor of the mouth and tongue are less frequently involved ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))
    - Mucosal lesions also may involve the vagina and nose and only rarely involve the conjunctivae ([Ophthalmology 2005;112:1809](16095701))+ Cutaneous lesions only precede gastrointestinal manifestations in ~15% of cases ([J Cutan Med Surg 2003;7:250](12574902))
      - Cutaneous lesions commonly involve the head and neck, particularly the face and scalp, as well as intertriginous areas and the vulva; however, pyodermatitis vegetans seldom involves the trunk and distal extremities ([JAAD Case Rep 2019;5:1078](31799357))- Oral lesions may arise prior to cutaneous lesions or appear concomitantly ([J Cutan Med Surg 2003;7:250](12574902))

Pathophysiology

* Pathogenic mechanisms that drive pyostomatitis vegetans have not been fully characterized
  + It has been postulated that an abnormal immune response in a background of inflammatory bowel disease causes a cross reaction of unidentified antigens in the skin, oral mucosa and bowel, ultimately producing mucocutaneous lesions ([Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2013;11:A24](23524131), [Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))

Etiology

* Most researchers today contend that pyostomatitis vegetans is a rare oral manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease; 73% of cases of pyostomatitis vegetans are associated with inflammatory bowel disease ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389), [J Am Acad Dermatol 1989;21:381](2666469))
  + Of the inflammatory bowel diseases, ulcerative colitis is most frequently associated with pyostomatitis vegetans, affecting 70% of patients, whereas only 11% of cases are associated with Crohn's disease ([J Cutan Med Surg 2003;7:250](12574902))

Clinical features

* Pyostomatitis vegetans has a distinctive clinical presentation characterized by multiple, vegetating yellow pustules that coalesce, easily rupture and form mucosal erosions; these erosions cause folding and fissuring of the mucosa, often resulting in what is described as a snail track appearance ([J Am Acad Dermatol 2016;75:578](27349819), [Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))
  + Oral discomfort and pain vary and are not necessarily attributable to the presence of oral lesions, even in instances of extensive mucosal involvement ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))+ Patients may sometimes exhibit fever along with swollen and tender submandibular lymph nodes ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))* Similarly, cutaneous lesions are described as well demarcated, erythematous and yellow, exudative vegetating plaques ([JAAD Case Rep 2019;5:1078](31799357))* Though rare, periocular involvement manifests as blepharitis with ulceration of the eyelid margins ([Ophthalmology 2005;112:1809](16095701))

Diagnosis

* Pyostomatitis vegetans is diagnosed by correlating clinical features with a history of inflammatory bowel disease, peripheral eosinophilia, histopathologic findings and negative cultures of purulent discharge from lesions ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))

Laboratory

* Peripheral eosinophilia is seen in 90% of cases of pyostomatitis vegetans (absolute eosinophil count beyond 450 - 500 cells/μL in the peripheral blood) ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389), [Prim Care 2016;43:607](27866580), [Ann Gastroenterol 2013; 26:187](24714872))
  + Anemia may also be observed (hemoglobin levels < 12.0 g/dL in women and < 13.0 g/dL in men) ([Ann Gastroenterol 2013 26:187](24714872), [Semin Hematol 2015;52:261](26404438))
    - Organism culture studies of purulent discharge from lesions are negative for pathogenic organisms ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))

Prognostic factors

* Prognosis for pyostomatitis vegetans is generally favorable, especially with appropriate management of the underlying inflammatory bowel disease ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))

Case reports

* 18 year old woman with a 2 month history of exophytic, yellowish, erosive lesions of the attached and unattached oral mucosa as well as the tongue ([Oral Maxillofac Surg 2024;28:1405](38467949))* 30 year old woman with a 6 week history of diffuse, painful breakout of velvety plaques in her mouth ([J Am Acad Dermatol 2005;52:722](15793543))* 35 year old woman with coalescing pustules of the oral and vaginal mucosa in addition to cutaneous involvement of the axilla and genital area ([Br J Dermatol 2003;149:181](12890215))* 58 year old man referred for white, purulent lesions of the gingiva ([Ann Gastroenterol 2013;26:187](24714872))* 62 year old man with multiple shallow, snail track-like gingival erosions that are painful with toothbrushing ([ScienceDirect: Pyostomatitis vegetans associated with ulcerative colitis - A case report [Accessed 4 June 2025]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S221255582500081X))

Treatment

* Treatment approaches are variable
  + Management of pyostomatitis vegetans is primarily based on managing the causative gastrointestinal disease ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))+ First line therapy for oral lesions typically consists of topical corticosteroids, such as triamcinolone acetonide and antiseptic mouthwashes (e.g., chlorhexidine) ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389), [Clin Exp Dermatol 2004;29:1](14723710))+ Steroid sparing regimens include the use of azathioprine, dapsone and sulfamethoxypyridazine ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))+ Methotrexate and infliximab have also demonstrated success in managing pyostomatitis and concomitant Crohn's disease ([Br J Dermatol 2003;149:181](12890215))

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Pronounced intraepithelial edema and spongiosis that resembles acantholysis
  + Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia with associated intraepithelial clefting, acanthosis, hyperkeratosis and reactive, multinucleated keratinocytes may also be observed ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389), [Clin Exp Dermatol 2004;29:1](14723710))+ This appearance of the epithelium is attributable to numerous eosinophils infiltrating and accumulating in the spinous layer, frequently forming abscesses ([Clin Exp Dermatol 2004;29:1](14723710))
      - These abscesses also contain neutrophils; abscesses may rupture, producing surface ulceration ([Clin Exp Dermatol 2004;29:1](14723710))- Underlying connective tissue harbors a mix of acute and chronic inflammatory cells, including eosinophils, lymphocytes, neutrophils and plasma cells ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2009;14:E114](19242389))+ Subepithelial eosinophilic abscesses and perivascular inflammation may also be seen

Sample pathology report

* Anterior maxillary gingiva, right, incisional biopsy:
  + Epithelial acanthosis with intraepithelial, neutrophilic and eosinophilic abscesses (see comment)+ Subepithelial acute and chronic inflammation+ Comment: The histologic features, which include intraepithelial abscesses, spongiosis and hyperplasia of the epithelium, are suggestive of pyostomatitis vegetans. Pyostomatitis vegetans is an oral manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease). The patient should be evaluated for gastrointestinal disease.

Differential diagnosis

* **Pemphigus vegetans**:
  + Contorted / vegetative epithelial hyperplasia, as well as intraepithelial neutrophils and eosinophils+ True suprabasilar acantholysis is present ([JAAD Case Rep 2022;25:67](35769193))
      - Direct immunofluorescence studies demonstrate intraepithelial deposits of IgG and complement; indirect immunofluorescence studies identify circulating antiepithelial IgG antibodies ([JAAD Case Rep 2022;25:67](35769193), [Hautarzt 1987;38:371](3308773))+ Pemphigus vegetans is a rare variant of pemphigus (an autoimmune blistering condition) and is not directly linked to irritable bowel disease ([Am J Dermatopathol 2013;35:e53](23221471))* [Paraneoplastic pemphigus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityparaneoplasticpemphigus.html):
    + Paraneoplastic pemphigus is invariably associated with neoplasms, including hematologic malignancies and carcinomas of the colon, lung and stomach ([Int J Mol Sci 2017;18:2532](29186863))+ Ulcerated squamous mucosa with keratinocyte necrosis, intraepithelial clefting and acantholysis+ Deep lymphohistiocytic, lichenoid inflammatory infiltrate causing perivascular inflammation ([JAAD Case Rep 2021;10:82](33778141), [Int J Mol Sci 2017;18:2532](29186863))+ Direct immunofluorescence studies demonstrate linear basilar deposits of C3, IgA, IgG and IgM; indirect immunofluorescence studies reveal circulating autoantibodies that target intraepithelial areas of stratified squamous or transitional epithelium ([JAAD Case Rep 2021;10:82](33778141), [Int J Mol Sci 2017;18:2532](29186863))* [Pemphigus vulgaris](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypemphigus.html):
      + Intraepithelial blister formation, suprabasilar acantholysis and subepithelial chronic inflammation+ Basal keratinocytes remain intact and acquire a cuboidal shape, creating a row of tombstones appearance ([Annu Rev Pathol 2016;11:175](26907530))+ Direct immunofluorescence studies reveal intraepithelial deposition of IgG and C3, creating a characteristic chicken wire or fishnet appearance ([Indian Dermatol Online J 2017;8:1](28217464))+ Indirect immunofluorescence studies have found that 80% of patients with pemphigus possess circulating IgG antibodies targeting desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, critical glycoproteins of desmosomes that are responsible for maintaining epithelial adhesion ([Annu Rev Pathol 2016;11:175](26907530))* [Oral lichenoid drug reaction](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumordrugreaction.html):
        + Various classes of medications have been implicated, including anxiolytics, antibiotics, anticonvulsants, antidiabetics, antifungals, antimalarials, antiretrovirals, various biologic agents, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and statins ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))
          - Dental restorative materials (e.g., amalgam), topical products and flavoring agents (e.g., cinnamon) have also been linked to these reactions ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))+ Histopathologically reminiscent of lichen planus; however, the inflammatory infiltrate often extends deep into the connective tissue, causing perivascular inflammation
            - Inflammatory infiltrate is composed of lymphocytes, histiocytes, plasma cells and occasional eosinophils ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))* [Lichen planus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitylichenplanus.html):
          + Civatte bodies dispersed throughout orthokeratinized or parakeratinized epithelium+ Hydropic degeneration of the basal cell layer and thickening of the basement membrane
              - Epithelial rete ridges assume a saw toothed appearance as a result of basal cell layer degeneration+ Tight band of lymphohistiocytic inflammation located directly beneath the surface epithelium+ Direct immunofluorescence reveals shaggy deposition of fibrinogen at the basement membrane zone ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2016;122:332](27401683))* [Mucous membrane pemphigoid](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypemphigoid.html):
            + Clean separation between surface epithelium and underlying connective tissue at the basement membrane zone ([Front Immunol 2019;10:34](30740099))
              - Area of separation often contains extravasated erythrocytes, corresponding to a hemorrhagic bulla+ Direct immunofluorescence studies reveal linear deposition of IgG at the basement membrane zone, with IgA and C3 deposition less commonly observed ([JAMA Dermatol 2021;157:780](33909024))
                - IgG or IgA antibodies target proteins of the basement membrane, including BP180, BP230, alpha 6 integrin, beta 4 integrin or laminin 332 ([JAMA Dermatol 2021;157:780](33909024), [J Dent Res 2001;80:1711](11669480), [J Immunol 2000;165:2824](10946315), [Biomolecules 2022;12:1461](36291670))+ Indirect immunofluorescence demonstrates circulating IgG autoantibodies against the aforementioned basement membrane proteins ([Annu Rev Pathol 2016;11:175](26907530))
